August Valentine Kautz

1828-01-05 – 1895-09-04

Member of Kautz family

Alternate name(s)

  • August Kautz

Biographical Information

August Valentine Kautz was a German-Ammerican officer in the U.S. military who served in the American Civil War. He published two issues of his newspaper Truth Teller in defense of Chief Leschi before Leschi's execution in 1858.

Spouse(s)

  • Tenas Puss (m. 1853-07)
  • Charlotte Todd Kautz (m. 1865-09-14)
  • Fannie Markbreit Kautz (m. 1872-11-27)

Augustus Kautz

1859-02-09 – 1935-02-23

Member of Kautz family

Alternate name(s)

  • Agustus Kautz
  • Augustus Doctin Kautz
  • Doctin Kautz

Parent(s)

Charlotte Todd Kautz

1845 – 1868-08-06

Member of Kautz family

Alternate name(s)

  • Charlotte Delamater Tod
  • Charlotte Kautz
  • Charlotte Todd
  • Mrs. Kautz

Biographical Information

Charlotte Todd Kautz was the daughter of Governor David Todd. She married August Valentine Kautz in 1865.

Spouse(s)

August Valentine Kautz

  • Newsletters about Charlotte Todd Kautz

Return to top



Eliza C. Porter

Alternate name(s)

  • Eliza Porter

Biographical Information

First public school teacher in Chicago, at Fort Dearborn, established normal schools, educated settlers and American Indians at Mackinac Island, aided the wounded during the American Civil War as a member of the U.S. Sanitary Commission, participated in the Underground Railroad, and taught freedmen.

Spouse(s)

Jeremiah Porter

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Eliza C. Porter
    • The Pacific Northwest and the United States Sanitary Commission: A Matter of Relevance (Winter 2014)

Erasmus D. Keyes

Alternate name(s)

  • Erasmus Keyes

Biographical Information

Served at Ft. Steilacoom as commander of Company M, 3rd Artillery beginning in November 1855–Spring 1856

Return to top



Fannie Markbreit Kautz

1849 – 1913-08-11

Member of Kautz family

Alternate name(s)

  • Fannie Kautz
  • Fannie Markbreit
  • Mrs. Kautz

Biographical Information

Fannie Markbreit Kautz was a German-American woman who married August Valentine Kautz in 1872. She was known as a socialite talented in dramatics, singing, and painting, and as a charitable woman.

Spouse(s)

August Valentine Kautz

George McClellan

Alternate name(s)

  • George B. McClellan

Biographical Information

American soldier, Civil War Union general, civil engineer, railroad executive, and politician who served as the 24th governor of New Jersey.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about George McClellan
    • Dr. George Suckley, Assistant Surgeon, U.S. Army, Naturalist and Author (Summer 2020)

Isaac Ingalls Stevens

1818-03-25 – 1862

Alternate name(s)

  • Isaac I. Stevens
  • Isaac Stevens

Biographical Information

Isaac Ingalls Stevens was the first territorial governor of the Washington Territory.

Spouse(s)

Margaret "Meg" Hazard Stevens

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Isaac Ingalls Stevens

Jeremiah Porter

Biographical Information

Reverend Jeremiah Porter, a Yankee Presbyterian evangelist, is considered Chicago's First Reformer

Return to top



John Baptist Brondel

Biographical Information

A Belgian-born prelate of the Catholic Church. He served in Canada as Bishop of Vancouver Island (1879–83) and in the United States as Bishop of Helena (1884–1903).

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about John Baptist Brondel
    • The Catholic Connection to Fort Steilacoom (Spring 2016)

Return to top



John Ector

Biographical Information

Brother in law of Paymaster Major A.B. Ragan. Ector suffered from some form of mental illness which resulted in violent outbursts and eventually led to his being admitted to an asylum.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about John Ector
    • Remembrances of Fort Steilacoom (Autumn 2018)

John Fulton Reynolds

Alternate name(s)

Biographical Information

A career United States Army officer and a general in the American Civil War.

Joseph Lane

Biographical Information

American politician and soldier appointed as the first Governor of Oregon Territory.

Return to top



Joseph Miles

Biographical Information

Militiaman in the citizen militia of Captain Charles Eaton; killed in a skirmish with the Nisqually people, and whose death was blamed on Chief Leschi

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Joseph Miles
    • Indian Attack on Connell’s Prairie (Summer-Autumn 2019)

Joseph Thomas Heath

Alternate name(s)

  • Joseph Heath

Biographical Information

Tenant farmer of land which later became the site for Fort Steilacoom

Ktsap

Died 1860-04-18

Member of Suquamish

Alternate name(s)

  • Kitsap

Biographical Information

Return to top



Kussass

Member of Snoqualmie Skykomish

Biographical Information

Kussass was a chief of the Skykomish. He was one of six men arrested for the death of Leander Wallace at Fort Nisqually in 1849, and one of two executed.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Kussass
    • Washington’s Yesterdays (Winter-Spring 2019)

Lafayette Balch

Biographical Information

European-American settlement at Steilacoom began with Lafayette Balch, a sea captain from Maine,

Lame Deer

1821 – 1877-05-10

Member of Miniconjou

Biographical Information

1st chief of the Minneconjon band of Dakota or Sioux Indians. Second signatory of the 1865 Treaty with the Minneconjon Indians

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Lame Deer

Return to top



Leschi

1808 – 1858-02-19

Member of Nisqually

Biographical Information

War chief of the Nisqually Tribe; accused, tried, and convicted of the murder of two militiamen in a skirmish with his people.

Parent(s)

  • Lahalet

Return to top



Louis Rossi

Biographical Information

A Catholic missionary priest who ministered for just over three years, from 1856 to 1860 in Washington Territory and then for almost three more years in northern California.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Louis Rossi
    • William H. Archbolt, The Ordnance Sergeant of Fort Steilacoom, Part 2 (Spring 2017)
    • The Catholic Connection to Fort Steilacoom (Spring 2016)

Lucile Saunders McDonald

1898 – 1992

Alternate name(s)

  • Lucile McDonald

Biographical Information

Lucile Saunderes McDonald was a Pacific Northwest journalist, historian, and author.

Return to top



Marcus Whitman

Biographical Information

An American physician and missionary who was killed, along with his wife and 11 other settlers, by a group of Cayuse peoples in an event that came to be known as the Whitman Massacre

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Marcus Whitman
    • The Cayuse, the Whitmans, and the Courts (Summer 2005)

Michael Luark

Biographical Information

An early settler who was hired in 1854 to work on the construction of the Steilacoom Court house

Newsletters

There are currently no newsletters about Michael Luark.

Mother Joseph

Biographical Information

A Canadian Religious Sister who led a group of the members of her congregation to the Pacific Northwest of the United States and established a network of schools and healthcare to service the American settlers

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Mother Joseph
    • For Her Time and Before Her Time, Mother Joseph, the Executive (Jul-95)

Patkanim

Member of Snoqualmie Snohomish

Alternate name(s)

  • Pat Kanim
  • Pat-ka-nam

Biographical Information

Chief Patkanim was chief of the Snoqualmie and Snohomish tribe.

Return to top



Qualchan

Died 1858-09-24

Member of Yakama Klickitat

Alternate name(s)

  • Qualchin

Biographical Information

Qualchan was a Yakama chieftain of the We-ow-icht family. He was a warrior and participated in the Yakama War. He was executed by the U.S. Army in 1858.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Qualchan
    • Remembrances of the Indian War 1855-1856 (Winter 2020)
  • Newsletters about subjects from similar demographics
    • Indigenous people of America
      • Tenas Puss
      • Spotted Elk

      • Sturharnai
      • Talatarn
      • Whyesk
      • Quatthlinkyne

  • Indigenous people of America
Return to top



Quallahwowt

Member of Snoqualmie

Biographical Information

Quallahwowt was a sub-chief of the Snoqualmie tribe. He was one of six men arrested for the death of Leander Wallace at Fort Nisqually in 1849, and one of two executed.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Quallahwowt
    • Washington’s Yesterdays (Winter-Spring 2019)
  • Newsletters about subjects from similar demographics
    • Indigenous people of America
      • Tenas Puss
      • Spotted Elk

      • Ktsap

      • Plenty Horses
      • Red Cloud
      • Istachus
      • Wapowety
      • Quiemuth
      • Slug-yeh
      • John Mollhigh
      • Utsalawah
      • Qualchan
      • Patkanim
      • Lahalet
      • Kussass
      • Sturharnai
      • Talatarn
      • Whyesk
      • Quatthlinkyne

Demographic(s)

  • Indigenous people of America
Return to top



Quatthlinkyne

Biographical Information

Quatthlinkyne was one of six men arrested for the death of Leander Wallace at Fort Nisqually in 1849.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Quatthlinkyne

Quiemuth

Member of Nisqually

Biographical Information

Older brother of Chief Leschi

Return to top



Red Cloud

1822 – 1909-12-10

Member of Oglala

Biographical Information

One of the most important leaders of the Oglala Lakota from 1868 to 1909.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Red Cloud
    • Edward Wanton (Ned) Casey (Winter 2008)

Richard Arnold

Biographical Information

In charge of construction at Fort Steilacoom 1854 – 1855

Silas Casey II

1807 – 1882

Member of Casey family

Abigail "Abby" Perry Pearce Casey

Return to top



Sturharnai

Biographical Information

Sturharnai was one of six men arrested for the death of Leander Wallace at Fort Nisqually in 1849.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Sturharnai
    • Washington’s Yesterdays (Winter-Spring 2019)

Biographical Information

Talatarn was one of six men arrested for the death of Leander Wallace at Fort Nisqually in 1849.

Tenas Puss

1838 – 1891

Member of Kautz family

Member of Nisqually

Alternate name(s)

  • Etta
  • Kitty
  • Kitty Etta Nisqually
  • Kitty Etta Quaymuth
  • Kitty Kautz
  • Little Kitten

Biographical Information

Tenas Puss (Little Kitten) was a Nisqually woman who married August Valentine Kautz in the 1850s. She was called Etta or Kitty in English.

Parent(s)

  • Quiemuth

Spouse(s)

August Valentine Kautz

Return to top



Wapowety

Member of Nisqually

Biographical Information

American Indian guide who helped lead Lieutenant August Kautz on the first recorded attempted ascent of Mount Rainier.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Wapowety
    • Climbing Mount Rainier (Winter 2017)

Return to top



Whyesk

Biographical Information

Whyesk was one of six men arrested for the death of Leander Wallace at Fort Nisqually in 1849.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Whyesk
    • Washington’s Yesterdays (Winter-Spring 2019)

Return to top



American Fur Company

Started 1808; ended 1847

Biographical Information

The American Fur Company was founded in 1808 by John Jacob Astor to establish a series of fur trading posts at the mouth of the Columbia, at today's Astoria, Oregon.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about American Fur Company
    • The Boundary Question (Autumn 2015)
Return to top



Hudson's Bay Company

Started 1670-05-02

Biographical Information

The Hudson's Bay Company was established by royal charter from King Charles II in 1670.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Hudson's Bay Company
    • The Boundary Question (Autumn 2015)
    • Building Fort Steilacoom—Part 1 (Spring 2012)
    • The Pig War—Soldiers Occupy San Juan Island (Winter 2011)
    • S.S. Beaver (Summer 2011)
    • From Joseph Heath Farm to Fort Steilacoom Museum (Summer 2009)
    • Tales of Old Fort Steilacoom (Spring 2009)
    • Fort Steilacoom’s Return to History (Summer 2003)
    • A Christmas of 1859 at Fort Steilacoom (Winter 2002)
    • Company M, the 1st Artillery Regiment in Oregon Territory and at Fort Steilacoom, 1849-1853 (Apr-92)
Return to top



North West Company

Started 1779; ended 1821

Biographical Information

The North West Company was formed in Montreal in 1779 to directly compete with the Hudson's Bay Company in the fur trade.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about North West Company
    • The Boundary Question (Autumn 2015)
Return to top



Puget Sound Agricultural Company

Started 1840; ended 1934

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Puget Sound Agricultural Company
    • Washington’s Yesterdays (Winter-Spring 2019)
    • S.S. Beaver (Summer 2011)
    • Steilacoom and the Military (Autumn 2004)
    • Fort Steilacoom’s Return to History (Summer 2003)
    • The Legacy of Fort Steilacoom (Winter 1999)
Return to top



Union Pacific Railway

Started 1862

Alternate name(s)

  • Southern Pacific Transportation Company
  • Union Pacific Railroad
  • Union Pacific Railroad Company

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Union Pacific Railway
    • Silas Casey—The Man in the Uniform (Winter 2003)
Return to top



Politics

Definition

The set of activities that are associated with making decisions in groups, or other forms of power relations among individuals.

Newsletters

There are currently no newsletters about Politics.

  • Newsletters about narrower terms
    • US-Great Britain Relations (1)
      • The Boundary Question (Autumn 2015)
      • Oregon Treaty (1846) (1)
        • The Boundary Question (Autumn 2015)
Return to top



Movements

Definition

A coordinated group action focused on a political, social, or religious issue or ideology.

Newsletters

There are currently no newsletters about Movements.

  • Newsletters about narrower terms
    • Abolitionism (1)
      • A Marriage of Convenience—Connections Between Forts Nisqually and Steilacoom (Summer 2006)
    • Manifest Destiny (1)
      • South of the Border—From Vera Cruz to Mexico City (Summer 2004)
Return to top



Abolitionism

Alternate term(s)

  • Abolition
  • Abolition of slavery

Definition

The movement to end slavery.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Abolitionism
    • A Marriage of Convenience—Connections Between Forts Nisqually and Steilacoom (Summer 2006)
Return to top



Manifest Destiny

Definition

A widely held cultural belief in the 19th-century United States that American settlers were destined to expand across North America.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Manifest Destiny
    • South of the Border—From Vera Cruz to Mexico City (Summer 2004)
Return to top



Nativism

Definition

The political policy of promoting or protecting the interests of native or indigenous inhabitants over those of immigrants, including the support of immigration-restriction measures.

Newsletters

There are currently no newsletters about Nativism.

Return to top

Indian Agent

Definition

An individual authorized to interact with American Indian tribes on behalf of the government.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Indian Agent
    • Steilacoom and the Military (Autumn 2004)
Return to top



American Indian Removal (1830-1847)

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about American Indian Removal (1830-1847)
    • Into the Florida Swamps—Casey Fights the Seminoles (Spring 2004)
  • Newsletters about narrower terms
    • Indian Removal Act of 1830 (1)
      • Into the Florida Swamps—Casey Fights the Seminoles (Spring 2004)
Return to top



Indian Removal Act of 1830

Definition

Authorized the president to negotiate with southern Indigenous tribes for their removal to federal territory west of the Mississippi River in exchange for white settlement of their ancestral lands.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Indian Removal Act of 1830
    • Into the Florida Swamps—Casey Fights the Seminoles (Spring 2004)
  • Newsletters about broader terms
    • American Indian Removal (1830-1847) (1)
      • Into the Florida Swamps—Casey Fights the Seminoles (Spring 2004)
Return to top



Treaty of Medicine Creek (1854)

Definition

Treaty granted 2.24 million acres of land to the United States in exchange for establishment of three reservations, cash payments over a period of twenty years, and recognition of traditional native fishing and hunting rights.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Treaty of Medicine Creek (1854)
    • S.S. Beaver (Summer 2011)
    • Steilacoom and the Military (Autumn 2004)
    • Fort Steilacoom’s Return to History (Summer 2003)
  • Newsletters about narrower terms
    • Medicine Creek Treaty Council (1)
      • Steilacoom and the Military (Autumn 2004)
Return to top



Medicine Creek Treaty Council

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Medicine Creek Treaty Council
    • Steilacoom and the Military (Autumn 2004)
  • Newsletters about broader terms
    • Treaty of Medicine Creek (1854) (3)
      • S.S. Beaver (Summer 2011)
      • Steilacoom and the Military (Autumn 2004)
      • Fort Steilacoom’s Return to History (Summer 2003)
Return to top



Permanent Indian Frontier (1840)

Definition

Land reserved through the Indian Removal Act of 1830 which was earmarked for the Native Americans and guaranteed the sovereignty and territorial integrity of the natives and their property.

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Permanent Indian Frontier (1840)
    • Into the Frontier—Casey’s First Post and Battle with Indians (Autumn 2002)
Return to top



US-Great Britain Relations

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about US-Great Britain Relations
    • The Boundary Question (Autumn 2015)
  • Newsletters about narrower terms
    • Oregon Treaty (1846) (1)
      • The Boundary Question (Autumn 2015)
Return to top



Oregon Treaty (1846)

Definition

A treaty between the United Kingdom and the United States that was signed on June 15, 1846, in Washington, D.C. and which brought an end to the Oregon boundary dispute

Newsletters

  • Newsletters about Oregon Treaty (1846)
    • The Boundary Question (Autumn 2015)
  • Newsletters about broader terms
    • US-Great Britain Relations (1)
      • The Boundary Question (Autumn 2015)
Return to top

Fraser Canyon Gold Rush (1858-1927)

Definition

Mass immigration of settlers to the area surrounding Fraser Canyon in British Columbia

Railroads

Definition

Railroad, mode of land transportation in which flange-wheeled vehicles move over two parallel steel rails, or tracks,

Ships

Definition

A large watercraft that travels the world's oceans and other sufficiently deep waterways, carrying goods or passengers, or in support of specialized missions, such as defense, research, and fishing.

      Artillery

      Definition

      A class of heavy military ranged weapons built to launch munitions far beyond the range and power of infantry firearms.

      Newsletters

      • Newsletters about Artillery
        • General Casey’s Post Fair Oaks Service (Autumn 2013)

      Barracks

      Definition

      A group of long buildings built to house military personnel or laborers.

      Discipline

      Definition

      A set of expectations that are required by any governing entity including the self, groups, classes, fields, industries, or societies.

      Newsletters

      There are currently no newsletters about Discipline.

      American Revolutionary War (1775-1783)

      Definition

      An armed conflict between the American colonies and Great Britain, secured a United States of America independent from Great Britain.

      Newsletters

      • Newsletters about American Revolutionary War (1775-1783)
        • The Caseys of Rhode Island (Spring 2003)
      • Newsletters about broader terms
        • Wars and Conflicts (19)

      Mexican-American War (1846-1848)

      Definition

      An armed conflict between the United States and Mexico from 1846 to 1848 following the 1845 U.S. annexation of Texas

      Newsletters

      • Newsletters about Mexican-American War (1846-1848)
        • Isaac Ingalls Stevens (Spring 2014)
        • Elizabeth Rigney—A Living History Portrayal (Autumn 2005)

        Aztec Club

        Definition

        A military society founded in 1847 by United States Army officers of the Mexican–American War.

        Newsletters

        There are currently no newsletters about Aztec Club.

        Peninsula Campaign

        Definition

        A major Union operation launched in southeastern Virginia from March through July 1862, the first large-scale offensive in the Eastern Theater.

        Newsletters

        • Newsletters about Peninsula Campaign
          • Edward Wanton (Ned) Casey (Winter 2008)
          • Was Fair Oaks Fair to Casey? (Summer 2002)

        Pig War (1859)

        Definition

        A largely bloodless border confrontation between the United States and the British Colony of Vancouver Island

        Newsletters

        • Newsletters about Pig War (1859)
          • The Pig War—Soldiers Occupy San Juan Island (Winter 2011)
          • Stevens and Casey at War (Winter 1998)

        Puget Sound War (1855-1856)

        Alternate term(s)

        • Indian War (1855-1856)

        Definition

        An armed conflict that took place in the Puget Sound area of the state of Washington in 1855–56, between the United States military, local militias and members of the Indigenous tribes of the Nisqually, Muckleshoot, Puyallup, and Klickitat.

        Newsletters

        • Newsletters about Puget Sound War (1855-1856)
          • Remembrances of the Indian War 1855-1856 (Winter 2020)
          • Indian Attack on Connell’s Prairie (Summer-Autumn 2019)
          • Fort Steilacoom – Refuge during the Indian War (Autumn 2017)
          • Reminiscence of Lt. James McAllister’s Daughter Sarah McAllister Hartman (Autumn 2016)

        Second Seminole War (1835-1842)

        Definition

        A conflict from 1835 to 1842 in Florida between the United States and Indigenous groups collectively known as Seminoles.

        Newsletters

        • Newsletters about Second Seminole War (1835-1842)
          • Into the Florida Swamps—Casey Fights the Seminoles (Spring 2004)

        Massacre at Wounded Knee

        Definition

        A massacre of nearly three hundred Lakota people by soldiers of the United States Army.

        Newsletters

        There are currently no newsletters about Massacre at Wounded Knee.

        West Point

        Definition

        A United States service academy in West Point, New York. Originally established as a fort, it is the oldest of the five American service academies and educates cadets for commissioning into the United States Army.

        Newsletters

        • Newsletters about West Point
          • Into the Frontier—Casey’s First Post and Battle with Indians (Autumn 2002)
          • Silas Casey, USMA Class of 1826 (Spring 2002)

          Return to top



          Religion

          Definition

          A social-cultural system of designated behaviors and practices, morals, beliefs, worldviews, texts, sanctified places, prophecies, ethics, or organizations, that generally relates humanity to supernatural, transcendental, and spiritual elements.

          Newsletters

          • Newsletters about Religion

          Christianity

          Definition

          An Abrahamic monotheistic religion based on the life and teachings of Jesus of Nazareth.

          Newsletters

          • Newsletters about Christianity

          Catholicism

          Definition

          Core beliefs of Catholicism are found in the Nicene Creed. The Catholic Church teaches that it is the one, holy, catholic and apostolic church founded by Jesus Christ in his Great Commission, that its bishops are the successors of Christ's apostles, and that the pope is the successor to Saint Peter, upon whom primacy was conferred by Jesus Christ.

          Newsletters

          • Newsletters about Catholicism

          Priesthood

          Definition

          The office of the ministers of religion, who have been commissioned ("ordained") with the Holy orders of the Catholic Church

          Newsletters

          • Newsletters about Priesthood

          Missionary

          Definition

          A person sent on a religious mission, especially one sent to promote Christianity in a foreign country.

          Newsletters

          Protestantism

          Definition

          A form of Christianity that originated with the 16th-century Reformation,[a] a movement against, what its followers perceived to be, errors in the Catholic Church.

          Newsletters

          There are currently no newsletters about Protestantism.

          Episcopal Church

          Definition

          The Episcopal Church, based in the United States with additional dioceses elsewhere, is a member church of the worldwide Anglican Communion. It is a mainline Protestant denomination and is divided into nine provinces

          Newsletters

          • Newsletters about Episcopal Church
            • Chaplains at Fort Steilacoom (Winter 2015)

          Return to top



          Methodist Episcopal Church

          Definition

          The oldest and largest Methodist denomination in the United States from its founding in 1784 until 1939. It was also the first religious denomination in the US to organize itself on a national basis.

          Newsletters

          • Newsletters about Methodist Episcopal Church
            • Fort Steilacoom – Refuge during the Indian War (Autumn 2017)
            • Chaplains at Fort Steilacoom (Winter 2015)

              • Willis and Mary Ann Boatman, Pioneer Settlers (Jul-90)
          • Newsletters about narrower terms
            • Cholera (1)
              • Mary Wells Slaughter (Winter 2005)

              • The Cayuse, the Whitmans, and the Courts (Summer 2005)
              • Dr. Horace Wirtz, Army Surgeon (Sep-95)

              • The Pacific Northwest and the United States Sanitary Commission: A Matter of Relevance (Winter 2014)
            • Western Sanitation Commission (1)
              • The Pacific Northwest and the United States Sanitary Commission: A Matter of Relevance (Winter 2014)
            • Healthcare (1)
              • Dr. Horace Wirtz, Army Surgeon (Sep-95)
          Return to top



          Cholera

          Definition

          An infection of the small intestine spread mostly by unsafe water and unsafe food that has been contaminated with human feces containing the bacteria.

          Newsletters

          • Newsletters about Cholera
            • Mary Wells Slaughter (Winter 2005)
          • Newsletters about broader terms
            • Sanitation and Disease (5)
              • Dr. George Suckley, Assistant Surgeon, U.S. Army, Naturalist and Author (Summer 2020)

          Return to top



          Dysentery

          Definition

          A type of gastroenteritis most commonly caused by contamination of food and water with feces due to poor sanitation.

          Newsletters

          There are currently no newsletters about Dysentery.

          • Newsletters about broader terms
            • Sanitation and Disease (5)
              • Dr. George Suckley, Assistant Surgeon, U.S. Army, Naturalist and Author (Summer 2020)

          Medicine

          Definition

          The science and practice of caring for a patient, managing the diagnosis, prognosis, prevention, treatment, palliation of their injury or disease, and promoting their health.

          Newsletters

          • Newsletters about Medicine
            • The Cayuse, the Whitmans, and the Courts (Summer 2005)
            • Dr. Horace Wirtz, Army Surgeon (Sep-95)

          Measles

          Definition

          A highly contagious infectious disease spread through the coughs and sneezes of infected people.

          Newsletters

          There are currently no newsletters about Measles.

          Scurvy

          Definition

          A disease resulting from a lack of vitamin C.

          Newsletters

          Healthcare

          Definition

          The maintenance or improvement of health via the prevention, diagnosis, treatment, amelioration, or cure of disease, illness, injury, and other physical and mental impairments in people.

          Newsletters

          • Newsletters about Healthcare
            • Dr. Horace Wirtz, Army Surgeon (Sep-95)

            Entertainment

            Definition

            A form of activity that holds the attention and interest of an audience or gives pleasure and delight.

            Dances

            Definition

            Recreational activity allowing young people to interact in a socially acceptable setting

            Newsletters

            • Newsletters about Dances
              • The Pacific Northwest and the United States Sanitary Commission: A Matter of Relevance (Winter 2014)
              • Mary Wells Slaughter (Winter 2005)
              • A Christmas of 1859 at Fort Steilacoom (Winter 2002)

            Godey's Lady's Book

            Definition

            American women's magazine that was published in Philadelphia from 1830 to 1878. It was the most widely circulated magazine in the period before the Civil War.[

            Newsletters

            • Newsletters about Godey's Lady's Book
              • Godey’s Ladies Book (Spring 2010)

            Definition

              Sleighing

              Definition

              A winter pastime typically consisting of lying or sitting in a sleigh or sled and sliding down a hill of snow.

              Fort Steilacoom

              Definition

              One of the first military fortifications built by the U.S. north of the Columbia River in what was to become the State of Washington.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Fort Steilacoom
                • Company “M” Arrives at Steilacoom (Spring 2011)
                • Civil War Brings Changes to Fort Steilacoom (Summer 2010)
                • 1st Lt. William Alloway Slaughter—Casualty of the Indian War (Autumn 2009)
                • Tales of Old Fort Steilacoom (Spring 2009)
                • Edward Wanton (Ned) Casey (Winter 2008)
                • Casey in Washington Territory (Autumn 2008)
                • Thomas Lincoln—Fort Steilacoom’s Other Casey (Winter 2006)
                • The Army Sutler (Autumn 2006)
                • A Marriage of Convenience—Connections Between Forts Nisqually and Steilacoom (Summer 2006)
                • Lt. John Nugen 1830-1857 (Spring 2006)
                • Mary Wells Slaughter (Winter 2005)
                • Mrs. Colonel Silas Casey III (Abigail Perry Casey – Hostess, Socialite and Mother) (Spring 2005)
                • Steilacoom and the Military (Autumn 2004)
                • Fort Steilacoom’s Return to History (Summer 2003)
                • A Christmas of 1859 at Fort Steilacoom (Winter 2002)
                • Renovation of Ft. Steilacoom Officers’ Quarters (Spring 2001)
                • Reconstruction of Fort Steilacoom—1857-1858 (Spring 2001)
                • Old Army Dam is Unearthed (Summer 2000)
                • Memorial Weekend [Civil War event at park] (Summer 2000)
                • Projects Completed – Work in Progress (Spring 2000)
                • “Miracle Babies” Fort Steilacoom’s Youngest Members (Spring 2000)
                • Fort Steilacoom becomes Western StateHospital (Winter 1999)
                • The Legacy of Fort Steilacoom (Winter 1999)
                • Hipkins, more than a road in Lakewood (Autumn 1999)
                • Facts and Foibles of Historical Research – Lessons I have Learned (Autumn 1999)
                • Sesquicentennial (Autumn 1999)
                • Sesquicentennial Celebration in August (Summer 1999)
                • Signs of Spring and Civil War (Spring 1999)

              Return to top



              Historic Fort Steilacoom Association (1983-present)

              Definition

              Established in 1983, with the purpose of restoring and preserving historic Fort Steilacoom in order to perpetuate the significance of the site for the benefit of the public by operating a museum complex and a strong educational program stressing the role of the Fort in Northwest history.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Historic Fort Steilacoom Association (1983-present)
                • Touring Historic Fort Steilacoom (Summer 2018)
                • Nancy Covert (Spring 2017)
                • Reorganized and Expanded Research Center (Summer 2016)

              Return to top



              Preservation

              Definition

              Protection and care of cultural property including artworks, architecture, archaeology, and museum collections.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Preservation
                • Historic Fort Steilacoom Association—History of the Organization (Part 3) (Spring 2013)
                • Restoring Historic Fort Steilacoom (Spring 2007)
                • Richard Lyle Dunkin (Autumn 2005)
                • Hipkins, more than a road in Lakewood (Autumn 1999)

              Return to top



              Programming

              Definition

              Planned activities whose purpose is to promote services meant to inform the wider community about heritage assets and the need to utilise them.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Programming
                • Historic Fort Steilacoom Association—History of the Organization (Part 3) (Spring 2013)
                • What on Earth is “Living History?” (Summer 2008)
                • A Christmas of 1859 at Fort Steilacoom (Winter 2002)
                • Back to the past: Time Traveling in Steilacoom (Winter 2002)

              Centennial

              Definition

              100 year anniversary

              Restoration

              Definition

              The act of restoring something to its original state; may refer to: Conservation and restoration of cultural heritage

              Fort Steilacoom (1849-1868)

              Definition

              Founded by the U.S. Army in 1849 near Lake Steilacoom, among the first military fortifications built by the U.S. north of the Columbia River in what was to become the State of Washington, the fort was constructed due to civilian agitation about the massacre in 1847 at the Whitman (Waiilatpu) mission.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Fort Steilacoom (1849-1868)
                • Washington’s Yesterdays (Winter-Spring 2019)
                • Remembrances of Fort Steilacoom (Autumn 2018)
                • Historic Fort Steilacoom Association—History of the Organization (Part 1) (Autumn 2012)

              Return to top



              Oregon Trail

              Definition

              A 2,170-mile (3,490 km) east–west, large-wheeled wagon route and emigrant trail in the United States that connected the Missouri River to valleys in Oregon.

              Newsletters

              There are currently no newsletters about Oregon Trail.

              • Newsletters about broader terms
                • Settler-Colonialism (8)
                  • The Cayuse, the Whitmans, and the Courts (Summer 2005)
                  • Fort Steilacoom’s Return to History (Summer 2003)
                  • Peter Runquist, Soldier, Blacksmith, Pioneer (Autumn 2001)
                  • Christopher and Elizabeth Mahon—Washington Pioneers (Summer 2001)
                  • Hipkins, more than a road in Lakewood (Autumn 1999)
                  • What’s So Important about Fort Steilacoom (Apr-97)
                  • Willis and Mary Ann Boatman, Pioneer Settlers (Jul-90)
                  • Chinook Jargon: A Common Bond of Frontier Communication (Jan-90)
              Return to top



              Oregon Territory (1848-1859)

              Definition

              Organized incorporated territory of the United States that existed from August 14, 1848, until February 14, 1859, when the southwestern portion of the territory was admitted to the Union as the State of Oregon.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Oregon Territory (1848-1859)
                • The Boundary Question (Autumn 2015)
              • Newsletters about broader terms
                • Settler-Colonialism (8)
                  • The Cayuse, the Whitmans, and the Courts (Summer 2005)
                  • Fort Steilacoom’s Return to History (Summer 2003)
                  • Peter Runquist, Soldier, Blacksmith, Pioneer (Autumn 2001)
                  • Christopher and Elizabeth Mahon—Washington Pioneers (Summer 2001)
                  • Hipkins, more than a road in Lakewood (Autumn 1999)
                  • What’s So Important about Fort Steilacoom (Apr-97)
                  • Willis and Mary Ann Boatman, Pioneer Settlers (Jul-90)
                  • Chinook Jargon: A Common Bond of Frontier Communication (Jan-90)
              • Newsletters about narrower terms
                • Oregon Boundary Dispute (1)
                  • The Boundary Question (Autumn 2015)
              Return to top

              Return to top



              Oregon Boundary Dispute

              Definition

              A 19th-century territorial dispute over the political division of the Pacific Northwest of North America between several nations that had competing territorial and commercial aspirations in the region.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Oregon Boundary Dispute
                • The Boundary Question (Autumn 2015)

              Washington Territory (1853-1889)

              Definition

              Organized incorporated territory of the United States that existed from March 2, 1853, until November 11, 1889, when the territory was admitted to the Union as the State of Washington.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Washington Territory (1853-1889)
                • Washington’s Yesterdays (Winter-Spring 2019)
                • Isaac Ingalls Stevens (Spring 2014)
                • Casey in Washington Territory (Autumn 2008)
              • Newsletters about broader terms

              Settlers

              Definition

              Persons who have migrated to an area and established a permanent residence there, often to colonize the area.

              Newsletters

              Economics

              Definition

              The social science that studies the production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services.

              Railroads (industry)

              Definition

              Railroad, mode of land transportation in which flange-wheeled vehicles move over two parallel steel rails, or tracks,

              Return to top



              Argonauts

              Definition

              An alternative nickname for the 'Forty-Niners', the desperate poor from Europe who arrived to try to make their fortunes out of gold on the west coast of America in 1849.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Argonauts
                • On the New Frontier: Casey’s Pacific Coast Service (Winter 2004)
              • Newsletters about broader terms

              Return to top



              Engineering

              Definition

              The use of scientific principles to design and build machines, structures, and other items, including bridges, tunnels, roads, vehicles, and buildings.

              Forts

              Definition

              A military construction or building designed for the defense of territories in warfare, and is also used to establish rule in a region during peacetime.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Forts
                • Casey in Washington Territory (Autumn 2008)

              Fort Nisqually

              Definition

              An important fur trading and farming post of the Hudson's Bay Company in the Puget Sound area, part of the Hudson's Bay Company's Columbia Department.

              Fort Vancouver

              Definition

              A 19th-century fur trading post that was the headquarters of the Hudson's Bay Company's Columbia Department, located in the Pacific Northwest.

              Newsletters

              Fort Hamilton

              Definition

              A United States Army installation in the southwestern corner of the New York City borough of Brooklyn, the original fort was completed in 1831

              Return to top



              Waiilatpu Mission

              Definition

              Attempt by two missionary couples, Whitmans and Spaldings, to evangalize indigenous populations of the Pacific Northwest ending with the deaths of the Whitmans and 11 others at the hands of the Cayuse peoples, prompting Congress to declare Oregon a U.S. territory and precipitating the Cayuse war.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Waiilatpu Mission
                • The Cayuse, the Whitmans, and the Courts (Summer 2005)
              • Newsletters about broader terms
                • Places (4)
                  • Winter Life on Steilacoom Prairie (Dec-95)
                  • A View of the Life of Army Wife Henrietta M. Haller (Apr-95)
                  • Company M, the 1st Artillery Regiment in Oregon Territory and at Fort Steilacoom, 1849-1853 (Apr-92)
                  • Willis and Mary Ann Boatman, Pioneer Settlers (Jul-90)
              Return to top



              Joseph T. Heath Farm

              Puyallup Valley

              Definition

              Originally inhabited by the Puyallup people, the first white settlers in the region were part of the first wagon train to cross the Cascade Range at Naches Pass in 1853.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Puyallup Valley

              San Juan Islands

              Definition

              An archipelago in the Pacific Northwest of the United States between the U.S. state of Washington and Vancouver Island, British Columbia, Canada. The San Juan Islands are part of Washington state, and form the core of San Juan County.

              Newsletters

              There are currently no newsletters about San Juan Islands.

              Cultural Practice

              Definition

              The manifestation of a culture or sub-culture, especially in regard to the traditional and customary practices of a particular ethnic or other cultural groups.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Cultural Practice
                • Let it Rain (Mar-96)
                • Winter Life on Steilacoom Prairie (Dec-95)
              • Newsletters about broader terms
                • Indigenous History (15)
                  • Into the Frontier—Casey’s First Post and Battle with Indians (Autumn 2002)
                  • Old Army Dam is Unearthed (Summer 2000)
                  • The Legacy of Fort Steilacoom (Winter 1999)
                  • The Indian Family of August V. Kautz (Winter 1997)
                  • E. P. Alexander at Fort Steilacoom (Jul-97)
                  • August V. Kautz and His Indian Family (Apr-97)
                  • The Rescue of Enslaved Georgiana Passengers and Crew: A True Historical Drama (Jun-96)

              Cayuse

              Definition

              An Indigenous tribe in what is now the state of Oregon in the United States.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Cayuse

              Chinook

              Definition

              Chinookan peoples include several groups of Indigenous people of the Pacific Northwest in the United States who speak the Chinookan languages.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Chinook
                • Steilacoom and the Military (Autumn 2004)
              • Newsletters about broader terms

              Choctaw

              Definition

              An Indigenous people originally based in the Southeastern Woodlands, in what is now Alabama and Mississippi.

              Newsletters

              There are currently no newsletters about Choctaw.

              Creek

              Definition

              Muscogee Creek are a group of related indigenous peoples of the Southeastern Woodlands in the United States of America. Their original homelands are in what now comprises southern Tennessee, much of Alabama, western Georgia and parts of northern Florida.

              Newsletters

              There are currently no newsletters about Creek.

              • Newsletters about broader terms

              Return to top



              Dakota

              Definition

              An Indigenous tribe and First Nations band government in North America. They compose two of the three main subcultures of the Sioux people, and are typically divided into the Eastern Dakota and the Western Dakota.

              Newsletters

              There are currently no newsletters about Dakota.

              • Newsletters about broader terms
                • Nations and Peoples (11)

                  • President’s Report on Restoration (Jan-89)
                  • E.P. Alexander: Memoirs of Fort Steilacoom (Aug-89)
              Return to top



              Duwamish

              Definition

              A Lushootseed-speaking Indigenous tribe in western Washington, and the indigenous people of metropolitan Seattle, where they have been living since the end of the last glacial period (c. 8000 BCE, 10,000 years ago).

              Newsletters

              There are currently no newsletters about Duwamish.

              Haida

              Definition

              An indigenous group who have traditionally occupied Haida Gwaii, an archipelago just off the coast of British Columbia, Canada, for at least 12,500 years

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Haida

              Miccosukee

              Definition

              An Indigenous people, part of the Seminole nation until the mid-20th century, when they organized as an independent tribe

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Miccosukee

              Minneconjou

              Definition

              An Indigenous people constituting a subdivision of the Lakota people, who formerly inhabited an area in western present-day South Dakota

              Nez Perce

              Definition

              An Indigenous people presumed to have lived on the Columbia River Plateau in the Pacific Northwest region for at least 11,500 years.

              Paiute

              Definition

              Refers to three non-contiguous groups of indigenous peoples of the Great Basin. Although their languages are related within the Numic group of Uto-Aztecan languages, these three groups do not form a single set. The term "Paiute" does not refer to a single, unique, unified group of Great Basin tribes.

              Newsletters

              There are currently no newsletters about Paiute.

              • Newsletters about broader terms
                • Nations and Peoples (11)

              Pict

              Definition

              A group of peoples who lived in what is now northern and eastern Scotland (north of the Firth of Forth) during Late Antiquity and the Early Middle Ages.

              Newsletters

              There are currently no newsletters about Pict.

              Salish

              Definition

              An Indigenous Tribe of the Pacific Northwest of the US and SW Canada, identified by their use of the Salish languages which diversified out of Proto-Salish between 3,000 and 6,000 years ago

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Salish
                • President’s Report on Restoration (Jan-89)
              • Newsletters about broader terms

              Seminole

              Definition

              An Indigenous people who developed in Florida in the 18th century.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Seminole

              Groups of Indigenous tribes and First Nations peoples in North America.

              Skewahamish

              Definition

              A Lushootseed-speaking Indigenous people, located in present-day Washington in the United States. Also spelled Suquamish

              Newsletters

              There are currently no newsletters about Skewahamish.

              Steilacoom

              Definition

              A Coast Salish people who lived in the Puget Sound area of Washington state in the United States.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Steilacoom

              Stikine Tlingit

              Definition

              The Stikine people are a ḵwáan or regional group of the Tlingit, indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest Coast of North America. Their historical territory included Wrangell Island and other islands of the Alexander Archipelago, as well as the basin of the lower Stikine River.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Stikine Tlingit

              Squaxin Island

              Definition

              In the extreme southwestern part of Puget Sound in Mason County, Washington, United States, the island is a reservation of the Native American Squaxin Island Tribe

              Newsletters

              There are currently no newsletters about Squaxin Island.

              Yakama

              Alternate term(s)

              • Yakima

              Definition

              Originally occupied the area on both sides of the Columbia River and on the northern branches of the Yakama (formerly Tapteal) and Wenatchee Rivers in the state of Washington. Originally spelled "Yakima," the Yakama nation renamed itself to "Yakama" in the mid-1990s to more closely reflect the proper pronunciation in their native tongue.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Yakama
                • Casey in Washington Territory (Autumn 2008)
                • Mary Wells Slaughter (Winter 2005)

              Return to top



              Slavery

              Definition

              The state and condition of being a slave, someone forbidden to quit their service for an enslaver, and who is treated by the enslaver as their property.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Slavery
                • Casey’s Service Career Ends (Winter 2013)
                • Letter from a Civil War Soldier—1861 (Autumn 2011)
              • Newsletters about narrower terms
                • Self-Emancipated Persons (1)
                  • Letter from a Civil War Soldier—1861 (Autumn 2011)
              Return to top

              Trial

              Definition

              A coming together of parties to a dispute, to present information (in the form of evidence) in a tribunal, a formal setting with the authority to adjudicate claims or disputes.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Trial
                • The Cayuse, the Whitmans, and the Courts (Summer 2005)

                  • A Historical Court of Inquiry and Justice (3)

                    • Search for Art Leads to History (Mar-91)
              Return to top



              Chief Leschi Trial

              Definition

              Trial of Nisqually War Chief Leschi for the "murder" of two militiamen in 1856

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Chief Leschi Trial
                • Indian Attack on Connell’s Prairie (Summer-Autumn 2019)
                • The Catholic Connection to Fort Steilacoom (Spring 2016)
                • Chaplains at Fort Steilacoom (Winter 2015)

              Truth Teller

              Definition

              A series of print articles written by Lt. Kautz vigorously defending the innocence of Leschi

              A Historical Court of Inquiry and Justice

              Definition

              Organization for retrial of Cheif Leschi in 2004 resulting in his exoneration.

              Newsletters

              White River Massacre (1855)

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about White River Massacre (1855)
                • Remembrances of the Indian War 1855-1856 (Winter 2020)
              Return to top



              Whitman Massacre (1847)

              Definition

              The killing of the Washington missionaries Marcus Whitman and his wife Narcissa, along with eleven others, on November 29, 1847 by members of the Cayuse tribe who accused Whitman of having poisoned 200 Cayuse in his medical care; launched the Cayuse War.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Whitman Massacre (1847)
                • The Cayuse, the Whitmans, and the Courts (Summer 2005)
                • Fort Steilacoom’s Return to History (Summer 2003)
              Return to top

              Obituary

              Definition

              A news article that reports the recent death of a prominent person.

              Newsletters

              • Newsletters about Obituary
                • Nancy Covert (Spring 2017)
                • Jack Langston (Autumn 2012)
                • Robert “Bob” Demorest (Spring 2012)
              Return to top



              Technology

              Definition

              The continually developing result of accumulated knowledge and application in all techniques, skills, methods, and processes used in industrial production and scientific research.

              Newsletters

              There are currently no newsletters about Technology.

              Return to top
